But the other three people named above definitely are
in Radio Sweden. These people are confused by the BFA
situation. Mrs. Bergman, who talked with Si in Italy or
somewhere, was especially so. To her, BFA had now officially
taken over NAEBâ€™s international activities. But Mr. Poalsson,
her superior, did not have this idea, so we cannot definitely
conclude that Mrs. Bergman*s misunderstanding resulted from
anything Si intentionally said. But the confusion exists.
I explained patiently, and several times over, that
NAEB does many things, of which getting programs from abroad
and distributing them via our tape network is only one; that
Si was a past president of NAEB and past chairman of our
International Relations Committee; but that he no longer was
in either capacity. I also explained that NAEB did not have
a permanent office In Europe, and that I therefore was not
Its permanent European representative (as Mrs. Bergman had
hastily concluded).
I tried my best to define our separate organizations and
different spheres of Interest, and I hope with good effect.
But I definitely avoided showing any displeasure with BFA or
criticizing them. The Swedes are smart enough to figure out
that there is some overlapping of interests, of course, but
for the record let me state that I did not take off on BFA or
any of its organizers!
I heard portions of four shows. Portrait of a City
(Gothenberg) is one of several Swedish Radio Is contributing
to what I assume is a BFA series. It was done for BFA, and
was initiated at their suggestion. Quite good; well worth
carrying, especially for a station like KUOM, with a large
audience of Scandinavian descent; but good anyhow.
International Almanac is another BFA show being done for
them once a month. It interviews Swedes In the news, In the
example heard, an explorer and an opera singer. Also good
show, though a little more Swedish promotion than City Portrait.
Stockholmer's Diary is distributed through the Swedish
Radio agents in Burlington, Vermont, Mr. and Mrs. Gunnar
Christiansen. It is on the order of International Almanac,
is definitely pre-BFA in origin, and is not handled by BFA
at all.
